estimated_calories.notes: Calories can vary significantly based on the type and brand of candy. Common candies like chocolate bars or gummies typically fall within this range per standard serving (about 40-50g).

protein.notes: Candy is generally low in protein unless it contains nuts or dairy.

carbs.notes: Primary macronutrient in candy, mostly from sugars and refined carbohydrates.

fat.notes: Fat content varies; chocolate-based candies are higher in fat (e.g., cocoa butter), while gummies or hard candies are fat-free.

present: Iron (in some fortified candies or dark chocolate)
Trace amounts of potassium or magnesium (in dark chocolate)
key_vitamins_and_minerals.notes: Candy is not a significant source of vitamins or minerals unless fortified. Dark chocolate may offer small amounts of antioxidants (e.g., flavonoids).

health_benefits.notes: Minimal health benefits. Potential mood boost due to sugar-induced serotonin release. Dark chocolate may offer minor cardiovascular benefits from flavonoids.

common_allergens: Tree nuts or peanuts (in candies with inclusions)
dietary_concerns: High added sugar content (risk for blood sugar spikes, dental cavities)
Artificial colors or flavors (may cause sensitivities in some individuals)
High saturated fat (in chocolate or coconut-based candies)

healthier_recommendations: Choose dark chocolate (70% cocoa or higher) for less sugar and more antioxidants.
Opt for smaller portion sizes to reduce sugar intake.
Pair with nuts or fruit to add fiber/protein and slow sugar absorption.
Look for allergen-free alternatives if sensitivities exist (e.g., dairy-free, nut-free).
Avoid candies with artificial additives; select those with simpler ingredient lists.
